easy.title: A New Book Prize for Kids with Kid Judges
easy.summary: The famous Booker Prize is starting a special new award just for children's books. It's called the Children's Booker Prize and will begin in 2026. The first winner will be announced in 2027. What makes this prize really special is that children will help choose the winning books! There will be adult judges and child judges working together. The famous author Frank Cottrell-Boyce, who wrote the popular book 'Millions,' will be the main judge. The prize wants to find the best books for kids aged 8 to 12. At least 30,000 copies of the shortlisted books will be given to children for free. The organizers hope this will help more kids discover great books and get excited about reading. Other famous children's authors like Jacqueline Wilson think this is a wonderful idea. The winning author will get £50,000, which is a lot of money!

middle.title: Children's Booker Prize: A New Era in Children's Literature Recognition
middle.summary: The prestigious Booker Prize Foundation has announced the creation of a groundbreaking new literary award specifically for children's fiction. The Children's Booker Prize, scheduled to launch in 2026 with the first award ceremony in 2027, represents a significant expansion of the Booker brand into children's literature. This innovative prize features a unique judging panel comprising both adult professionals and child judges, marking a departure from traditional literary awards. Frank Cottrell-Boyce, the current UK Children's Laureate and acclaimed author of 'Millions,' will serve as the inaugural chair of judges. The selection process involves adult judges creating an eight-book shortlist, followed by the inclusion of three child judges to help determine the ultimate winner. A major component of the initiative involves distributing at least 30,000 copies of shortlisted and winning books directly to children, addressing accessibility issues in children's literature. The prize aims to identify 'future classics' while inspiring greater reading engagement among young people. With substantial financial rewards - £2,500 for shortlisted authors and £50,000 for the winner - the prize seeks to elevate the status of children's literature. The award will consider books originally written in English or translated into English, published in the UK or Ireland between November 2025 and October 2026. Prominent children's authors including Dame Jacqueline Wilson and Anne Fine have enthusiastically endorsed the initiative, viewing it as long-overdue recognition for the children's literature field.

background_read: The Booker Prize is one of the world's most prestigious literary awards, established in 1969 to recognize the best novel of the year written in English. Over decades, it has expanded to include the International Booker Prize for translated works. Children's literature has historically received less recognition in major literary awards compared to adult fiction. The role of UK Children's Laureate was created in 1999 to champion children's literature, with prominent authors like Quentin Blake, Michael Morpurgo, and Malorie Blackman serving in this position. Frank Cottrell-Boyce, the inaugural chair for this new prize, is an accomplished screenwriter and children's author known for his collaboration with filmmaker Danny Boyle. The inclusion of child judges represents a growing trend toward involving young people in decisions that affect them, reflecting broader educational principles about student voice and participation. The substantial prize money and book distribution initiative address ongoing concerns about literacy rates and equal access to quality literature among children from diverse socioeconomic backgrounds.

high.title: The Children's Booker Prize: Democratizing Literary Recognition and Addressing Accessibility in Children's Literature
high.summary: The Booker Prize Foundation has initiated a transformative expansion of its literary recognition framework with the establishment of the Children's Booker Prize, scheduled for launch in 2026 with inaugural awards in 2027. This groundbreaking initiative represents a strategic diversification of the Booker brand into the children's literature domain, characterized by its innovative dual-judging structure incorporating both established literary professionals and child participants. The prize specifically targets contemporary fiction for readers aged 8-12, with Frank Cottrell-Boyce, the incumbent UK Children's Laureate and celebrated author of 'Millions,' appointed as inaugural chair of judges. The selection methodology involves a phased approach: three adult judges, including Cottrell-Boyce, will curate an eight-book shortlist, subsequently joined by three child judges for the final winner selection. A particularly significant component is the commitment to distribute at least 30,000 copies of shortlisted and winning titles directly to young readers, constituting a substantial intervention in literary accessibility. Gaby Wood, Chief Executive of the Booker Prize Foundation, characterizes this as their most ambitious undertaking in two decades, with objectives encompassing the identification of 'future classics' and inspiration of youth reading engagement. The financial structure mirrors established Booker protocols, with £2,500 allocations for shortlisted authors and a £50,000 grand prize. Eligibility criteria encompass global authorship with requirements for English language publication (original or translated) in the UK or Ireland within the November 2025 to October 2026 publication window. The initiative has garnered endorsement from literary luminaries including Dame Jacqueline Wilson and Anne Fine, the latter characterizing children's literature as 'the overlooked Cinderella of the book world.' This development occurs within broader contextual debates regarding literary canon formation, intergenerational collaboration in cultural evaluation, and equitable access to literary resources.

Children's literature has historically occupied a marginalized position within literary hierarchies, often dismissed as pedagogically oriented rather than artistically significant. The UK Children's Laureate position, inaugurated in 1999 with Quentin Blake, represents institutional recognition of children's literature's cultural importance. The Booker Foundation's expansion follows broader cultural institution trends toward intergenerational programming and audience development initiatives.

zh.title: 布克奖推出儿童小说新奖项，包括年轻评委参与评选
zh.summary: 著名的布克奖组织机构宣布推出一个专门针对儿童小说的新奖项，该奖项将由成人和儿童共同组成的评审团进行评选。儿童布克奖将于2026年启动，首届奖项将于2027年颁发，旨在表彰8至12岁儿童当代小说的最佳作品。英国儿童文学奖得主弗兰克·科特雷尔-博伊斯将担任首届评委会主席，他以其广受欢迎的作品《百万小兄弟》而闻名。评奖过程采用独特的两阶段模式：三位成人评委首先选出八本书的入围名单，然后由三名儿童评委加入共同决定最终获奖作品。该奖项的一个重要特点是承诺向儿童免费分发至少3万册入围和获奖图书，这显著提升了儿童文学的普及性。布克奖基金会首席执行官加比·伍德表示，这是他们20年来最具雄心的项目，旨在“倡导未来经典”并激励更多年轻人阅读。奖项奖金体系与布克奖保持一致，入围作者每人可获得2500英镑，获奖作者将获得5万英镑。该奖项面向全球作者开放，接受原版英文作品或英文翻译作品，只要这些作品在2025年11月至2026年10月期间在英国或爱尔兰出版。包括杰奎琳·威尔逊夫人和安妮·法恩在内的著名儿童文学作家都对这一倡议表示热烈欢迎，法恩将儿童文学形容为“图书世界中经常被忽视的灰姑娘”。这一创新奖项代表了儿童文学认可的重要发展，通过跨代合作和图书普及计划，为促进儿童阅读和文学发展开辟了新途径。
